meta.description: Gain exposure to cryptocurrencies, forex, equities, indices, and commodities on Ethereum with zero slippage

homepage.page-title: Kwenta | derivatives trading with infinite liquidity

assets.title: Trade real world assets and derivatives on Ethereum

infinite-liquidity.title: Infinite liquidity
infinite-liquidity.copy: All trading is peer-to-contract, using the Synthetix protocol’s pooled liquidity model. This means no counterparty matching, and essentially infinite liquidity for traders.

zero-slippage.title: Zero slippage
zero-slippage.copy: Infinite liquidity means that traders never have to worry about moving the orderbook and being affected by slippage.

synthetic-futures.title: Synthetic futures
synthetic-futures.copy: Once futures is built on the Synthetix protocol, it will soon be supported on Kwenta, offering perpetual future contracts on a non-custodial, permissionless platform.

l2.title: Now on Optimism layer 2
l2.copy: Kwenta can now be used on Optimism's layer 2 solution for <0>low gas fees</0> and <0>fast transactions</0>. Trade like an elite.
l2.disclaimer: * These statistics are approximations. User experience will vary.

markets.title: Live markets
markets.copy: Start trading now on Optimism layer 2

benefits.title: Without the limits of a centralised exchange

peer-to-contract.title: Peer-to-contract (P2C) trading
peer-to-contract.copy: All trades are executed against the Synthetix smart contracts, so traders don’t have to worry about the limitations of the peer-to-peer trading model, such as liquidity, slippage, or orderbooks.

trading-pair.title: No trading pair restrictions
trading-pair.copy: Any Synth can be traded instantly into any other Synth so you’re not restricted to whichever trading pairs the exchange offers, which is a necessary restriction of the centralised exchange model.

permissionless.title: Permissionless and non-custodial
permissionless.copy: Kwenta is a dApp that leverages the Synthetix protocol, which means no creating an account, no deposits or withdrawals, and no surrendering custody of your funds.

one.title: You’ll need a web3 wallet with ETH for gas
one.subtitle: Step One
one.copy: Kwenta is on the Ethereum blockchain, so like all other dApps on Ethereum you’ll need a web3 wallet with ETH in it as gas to pay for transactions to be processed. Popular cryptocurrency wallet categories include hardware wallets, browser extension wallets, and mobile wallets.

two.title: Acquire sUSD (or any other Synth)
two.subtitle: Step Two
two.copy: To start trading, you’ll need a synthetic asset derivative supported by Kwenta, known as Synths. The most accessible Synth is sUSD, which can be purchased on dApps such as Uniswap, Curve, or 1inch.

three.title: Use Kwenta to trade the full range of Synths
three.subtitle: Step Three
three.copy: Once you’ve got sUSD or any other Synth, you can trade between the entire range of Synths to craft a diverse portfolio of assets, all on-chain and without surrendering custody to an exchange!

qna1.question: What is Ethereum?
qna1.answer: Ethereum enables the creation of infrastructure that can exist entirely online, managed and run by a vast network of people, meaning that no-one controls it and it would be extremely difficult (if not impossible) to shut down. This puts it out of the reach of governments or other authorities.  Ethereum was created by a team of Bitcoin enthusiasts, who wanted to expand on its design of decentralized money to build out other decentralized use cases (‘decentralized’ means it’s not controlled by a central authority). There is a huge ecosystem of projects on the Ethereum blockchain, all of which can interact with each other.

qna2.question: What is DeFi?
qna2.answer: DeFi stands for decentralised finance, and represents an ecosystem of open financial tools, products, and protocols on Ethereum. Both Kwenta and the Synthetix protocol that it’s built on are part of the DeFi ecosystem. DeFi runs on smart contracts, which are a key feature of the Ethereum blockchain. Smart contracts are programs or protocols that execute or control certain events and actions according to however they’re coded. They allow for the creation of decentralised infrastructure that carries out certain tasks: for example, a smart contract that enables lending and borrowing will have smart contracts that lock funds that are deposited as collateral and enable users to borrow other assets against their own collateral.

qna3.question: What’s a dApp?
qna3.answer: dApp stands for decentralised application. dApps are frontend interfaces providing access to open-source protocols on the blockchain. If the underlying protocol is openly accessible, then there can be multiple dApps providing different interfaces for the same protocol/s. dApps allow people to use their cryptocurrency wallets to interact directly with smart contracts, meaning there’s no need to create accounts or make deposits or withdrawals, as users never need to surrender custody of their assets.

qna1.question: Where does the liquidity come from?
qna1.answer: Kwenta is built on the Synthetix protocol, so the Synth liquidity traders can access on Kwenta is entirely created by SNX stakers on Synthetix.

qna2.question: How does trading work if there are no counterparties?
qna2.answer: There are no direct counterparties for each trade in the Synthetix protocol, but it does use a counterparty-like model in which SNX stakers assume a proportion of the Synthetix debt pool when they mint sUSD. For more details, see the Synthetix <0>litepaper</0>.

qna3.question: How are the gas costs calculated?
qna3.answer: Transactions cost a certain amount proportional to how much processing power is required for Ethereum miners to process it. Kwenta uses the Synthetix protocol, which is far more complex than the majority of other Ethereum projects, so its transactions require more gas to be executed.
